Description: Fragment of double arched handle and shoulder of East Greek, probably Aeolian, grey ware pottery vessel, krater or hydria; interior reserved; exterior: worn dark grey slip on handles; incised pattern where handles join wall, perhaps the kalyx of a pendant volute palmette; plastic decoration (only lower part of probably bud remaining) between loops of handle.
Curator's comments: The fragment is strikingly similar to British Museum 1965,0930.439 and in the same style as the handle fragment of a jug or hydria found on Samos (Walter-Karydi, ‘Samos - VI/1 Samische Gefässe des 6. Jahrhunderts v. Chr.’, (Deutsches Archäologisches Institut), Bonn (1973), pl. 60, no. 497, with volute palmette in relief). The missing plastic decoration may have resembled the bud on British Museum 1888,0601.647.d. The fabric finds parallels with British Museum 1888,0601.644.c. This sherd was analysed with NAA by Hans Mommsen (Bonn). The origin of the fabric (NAUK 47) was not identified and considered a chemical singleton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GL.160)
